oai_dc:dc.dc:title: James Brown house: front door
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 9521 Ooltewah-Georgetown Road, Ooltewah, Hamilton Co., TN

Color photograph showing the front door of the house from an angled view. Half-columns of molded brick flank the door. The door frame includes a sidelight to each side of the door and a transome above. Rectangular windows are visible in the background. A modern metal screen door has been added. The interior door stands open. The limestone foundation of the house can be seen at bottom.

The James Brown Farmstead in Hamilton County, Tennessee has long been recognized as a landmark of Cherokee history, settlement, and removal. Its significance derives from its associations with James Brown, an important Cherokee leader from 1806 to 1863, and the themes of westward expansion, Cherokee nationalism, Cherokee removal, and the Trail of Tears..
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Dwellings; Historic buildings -- Tennessee; Brick houses
transom windows
